content:
Hello everyone. There are a range of possible errors that may encounter with Lab4 and Visual Studio 2012 (or higher), so I will try to clarify how they are solved in this announcement.
VS2012 introduced a new local database mechanism called SQL Server Local/DB which replaces the previous SQL Server Express. Unfortunately, there is not any backwards compatibility, so the original database I provided might not work If you see an error message about SQL Server Express or something like that, then that means you are using the wrong database file.
Another error is possible with the new Local/DB file.
Several students (including myself) discovered that no matter what they did, they started seeing a error message about not being about to connect to the database: "A network-related or instance-specific error occurred while establishing a connection to SQL Server. The server was not found or was not accessible. Verify that the instance name is correct and that SQL Server is configured to allow remote connections. (provider: SQL Network Interfaces, error: 50 - Local Database Runtime error occurred. Error occurred during LocalDB instance startup: SQL Server process failed to start"
 The solution to this problem is as follows:
1. Open a cmd window
2. type in the following commands:
sqllocaldb delete "v11.0"
sqllocaldb create "v11.0"
 
Finally, VS2012 has changed the interface for the New Query. In lab4, there are instructions (for instance on page 13) to the Add Table Dialog and other things that are no longer available in VS2012.  In previous versions of VS, there was a Microsoft Access style visual query builder but now it seems VS2012 only provides a command window for typing in SQL commands.

title: B215 database errors

content:
Hello everyone. I have uploaded the draft manuscript of the first JavaScript chapter for the second edition of the textbook.
You may remember that Ricardo and I are beginning to work on the second edition of our textbook. In the new edition, the JavaScript coverage is going to be substantially expanded. Instead of two chapters on JavaScript, it will have four chapters: ch 8 - Language Fundamentals, ch 9 - using javascript [DOM and events], ch 10 Extending JavaScript [jquery + ajax], and ch 20 Frameworks [angular + node.js].
I have completed and uploaded to Blackboard the manuscript for the language fundamentals chapter. It is a pdf of the Microsoft Word draft, so it doesn't have all the fancy formatting etc that the finished version will have. You are welcome to take a read through it if you are interested. Eventually in the fall, copy editors and proof readers will give it a closer read and fix up grammar problems and so on. What I would be interested in hearing now from any of you are "bigger" issues (e.g., "this explanation didn't make sense" or "this could use a better example" or "you should also talk about X here" etc). 
Of course, you are busy with a lot of courses right now so there is absolutely no expectation on any of you. However, if you do find yourself reading through parts of it over the next several months, and you do find yourself having opinions, I would be happy to hear them. You could do so via email or by using the comment feature in Acrobat.
At the very least, I think it might be helpful when studying for the final exam. As well, please don't distribute this file.
Randy
postedTo: COMP-4513 - Winter 2016 - Web III: Advanced Web Dev
title: JavaScript Chapter available

content:
Hello everyone. We are going to have our next quiz on Tuesday March 8.
As well, I have a favour to ask of all of you. I would love if you would be willing to fill out an online survey about your knowledge of the different computing disciplines. This is part of an on-going international research project for which I am one of main investigators. The survey takes about 10 minutes and is 100% optional and 100% anonymous. It asks a few demographic questions and then gives you a series of computing tasks (e.g., "Designs testing procedures for large scale systems"), and then asks you to rank on a scale of 1-5 whether you think it belongs to Computer Engineering, Computer Science, Information Systems, Information Technology, or Software Engineering. There are no right or wrong answers; we are interested in what computing tasks majors and non-majors think "belong" to different disciplines. Some respondents are familiar with these disciplines, while others are not knowledgeable. This survey helps us better understand what undergraduates know about these different computing disciplines in general. This research will help inform the construction of guidance counseling material (which is the last phase of this research). At any rate, me and my research team would be thrilled if you could spend 10 minutes to fill out the survey.
The URL for the survey is:
https://www.surveymonkey.com/ r/computing-disciplines 
Regards,
Randy

content:
Hello everyone. Being able to experiment with different environments is one of the key outcomes of COMP4513. For this reason, we will likely be using different approaches to set up and hand in our labs. For our first lab (lab 7), this is the system we are going to use:
1. Create a new user account on cloud9.
2. Create a new public HTML5 workspace named comp4513-lab7
3. You can code directly within the cloud9 ide if you haven't completed the lab. If you have already completed the lab, then simply upload all the files (under the File | Upload Local Files menu command).
4. test to make sure it works (use the preview button)
5. When it is ready to be marked, share it with me. Use the Share button in the upper right corner of your workspace. In the share dialog, invite me to have access to your workspace via my email (rconnolly@mtroyal.ca). Keep it as RW so I can add a note telling you if something needs to be fixed etc.
6. If it works, I should be able to test it. It would be great if someone can try this in the next 24 hours so I can verify that this approach works! :-)
Randy

content:
All presentations will take place on the last day of classes: Thursday Dec. 4. There will be 10 presentations so each group/person will be about 7-8 minutes, including transition time. We will need to make sure that not too much time is lost between groups, so we will need to be organized. 
You will likely want 2-3 slides. Pick one or two interesting things that you found. You can save the other stuff for the report! 
Using a random number generator I have come up with the following order of presentation:
title: Presentations (Edited)

content:
A couple of things to help you out. 
When creating your view for the training set, DO NOT INCLUDE the speed! You use speed to do the classification of good or poor but if you include speed in the view the algorithm will just build a rule on that, which is no use as you want to apply the rule to days that you do not have riding data for (and hence no speed). 
For your 'target' or classification I recomend using 0 or 1 to start with. 0 is poor, 1 is good. Once you get it to work you can try three values or to use text like 'good', 'bad'. Whatever you do you need to have your classification domain match the domain of the cost matrix 'actual value' and 'predicted value'.
title: Decision Tree Classifier Help

I have created some oracle examples. They are available in the directory: /users/library/csis/comp4522/Oracle 
auto_increment.sql : an example of using an Oracle sequence. This is Oracle's way of doing auto-increment. 
loops.sql : an example of PL/SQL loops. 
time_fmt.sql : an example of a PL/SQL function. 
datadict.sql : an example of using the Oracle data dictionaary.

It is under Assignments/Oracle Information.
It has details about your username and Oracle resources.

Course Link/Assignments/Oracle Information
title: Oracle!

content:
On Tuesday we will work through an example of buiilding a star schema for a data warehouse. 
On Thursday we will look at how to query a star schema and introduce data mininig. 
I will give out assignment 1 on Thursday. In it you will create a data warehouse using Oracle, perform some queries and analysis and a simple bit of data mining.
title: Week 3

content:
There is always something hopeful and optomistic about week 2.
I have posted the solution to the relational algebra handout. See Lectures->Week 1. 
Materials for Week 2 are in progress. We will have a quiz on Tues and move into Business Intelligence and data warehousing.
title: Week 2!

content: I have posted the materials for week 1. Note that the relational algebra sheet has been corrected. (The one handed out in class makes a mess of the minue operator). I created an example for minue and described it correctly.
title: Materials for Week 1

content:
Welcome to the Fall 2014 instance of Database II. I will be posting course outlines and all that other good stuff shortly, so watch this space.
There is no required text for this course (we jump around a bit so there is no text that really covers things).
We will be covering:
I will give you the usual midterm, final and a bunch of quizzes. There will be three assignments and a term project. The term project will be to take some large dataset and do some data mining on it. I have several sets of twitter tweets (#cdnpoli, #yyc, #worldcup) that we can use but other data is possible.
We will primarily be using Oracle for our data warehousing and data mining and we will implement a simple database using Cassandra.
title: Welcome!

content:
Welcome to a new semester at MRU, and welcome to Math 0115-065! The Blackboard website that will contain all the documents and links that you need for this course is now live. You can access this website via www.mymru.ca. Go to the Student tab and find the link for Blackboard. The name of the website is Math 0115-065 Introductory Algebra Fall 2016. 
Here is a brief checklist of items to take care of as soon as possible:
* Browse through the Blackboard website to familiarize yourself with its organization. The course outline can be found in the section "Introduction to this Course".
* Obtain a textbook and bring it to each class. The text is specified on the course outline. It is available in the university bookstore.
* Get ready to start homework problems! The homework problems are listed on Blackboard, in the section "Course Topics".
Reminder of Room Change:
Our room has been changed to:  Monday 9:00 - 10:50  EA1067      Wednesday, Friday 9:00 - 10:50  EA2013
Our first class is on Friday September 9 in room EA2013.
I look forward to seeing you on Friday.
Flora Serchuk (instructor for Math 0115-065)    email: fserchuk@mtroyal.ca
title: Welcome to Math 0115-065; Reminder of Room Change

content:
Hi all,
All information about the group project is posted now under "Information" on the left panel.
ALL members of a group are required to collaborate in the creation of the project and to attend the presentation next week. The members who are not in this tutorial are required to attend the presentation with the rest of the group.
All members should use the discussion board and email tools in their work.
Documents should be shared on the discussion group and the final presentation should be uploaded on this site.either as a PowerPoint or a poster picture and poster documents in word or pdf format.
Please let me know if you have any questions.
Mircea
MC Atanasiu
Instructor

content:
Hi Team,
The reading break (November 9 - 11) is quickly approaching. What does that mean in the world of peer tutoring?
If you normally tutor on Wednesday, Thursday, and/or Friday, please discuss with your student(s) whether or not you would like to hold your regular session during the break (except for November 11). If you'd like to reschedule for earlier that week, you are welcome to do so. Otherwise, please complete your "no sessions this week" form.
title: Reading Break

content:
Hi Everyone,
To view the most current list of unfilled requests, please visit this Google document. If you see a time that fits with your schedule or with a session you already run, let me know and I can arrange the match for you (whether this is adding a student to your total or adding a student into your existing session).
NOTE: This is a live document, so as students send me availability, I will make updates. Check back regularly if you're hoping for more students or a space opens up.
Thanks, Team!
title: Remaining Requests - Updated October 14

content:
Dear Students,
Last class we started working with the prepositions: POR and PARA.
I encourage you to have more avtivities and explanations looking at the link of studyspanish.com here on the BlackBoard under the content.
Also it is useful because of the listening and pronunciation.
Enjoy it!
title: Reading about Por and Para

content:
Hola a todos!
This message is to let you know that "Charlemos en Espanol" will start on October the 7th and it goes until November the 18th. It is very good time for register as soon as you can because the deadline is October the 1st!!
This is very good for you to practice the conversation in Spanish. You do not need to worry about anything, you just go to practice! it would be very helpful. Of course, this is if you have time and you can accomodate this in your schedule.
Good luck!
Adriana
title: Charlemos en Espanol

content:
Hola a todos!
Este es el Nivel 2 de Espanol en Otono.
Espero que disfruten de este curso a la vez que aprenden a usar el nuevo vocabulario y los nuevos temas, pondremos en practica lo que aprendamos en clase.
Buena Suerte!
Adriana
title: Bienvenidos al Curso de Espanol Nivel 2
Credit-free World Languages
